children.label: b41731163
children.title: A Stocktake of Existing Actions and Activities to Reduce Marine Plastic Litter and Microplastics

children.label: b41731897
children.text:
**Please Note:  The submission deadline has been extended so that responses submitted by the 11th February 2020 will be included in the first stocktake data report to UNEP in May 2020.  (Submissions after 11th February 2020 will be incorporated into a later report)**

We invite you to contribute to a voluntary online survey aimed at taking stock of existing activities and actions (starting from 1st January 2018) to reduce marine plastic litter and microplastics.

Macro- and microplastics in the environment are a main area of concern to the general public, policy makers and scientists. We are aware of some excellent, innovative programmes to tackle the problem but we would like to know more about these and other initiatives. We want to learn from countries about their challenges and solutions, about existing activities and actions and showcase best practices.

Who is leading this Survey?

This survey is being undertaken by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), in response to resolution  UNEP/EA.4/Res.6  paragraph  7, which requests, through subparagraph 7(a) to: “Take stock of existing activities and action by governments, regional and global instruments, international organizations, the private sector, non-governmental organizations and other relevant contributors to reduce marine plastic litter and microplastics with the aim of the long-term elimination of discharge into the oceans”.  The survey is administered by the University of Plymouth in collaboration with UNEP.

What are the aims of the Survey?

The aim is to take stock of existing activities taken to prevent and reduce marine plastic litter and microplastics, to provide a snapshot of the current situation. The results will be used to produce a stocktaking report with a situational analysis of categories of actions and themes (e.g., along the life cycle, geographic range, environmental zone, and the existence of reporting and evaluation practices). This analysis will show the distribution and focus of current actions and activities and and will be made available through the UNEP website to inform further discussions of the ad hoc open-ended experts group on marine litter and microplastics in preparation for the fifth session of the UN Environment Assembly.

children.label: b42272835
children.text:
How will the data be analysed and validated?  Who will have access to the information?

There are two key outcomes, a report and a searchable online dashboard. Data on the activities and actions will be publicly available and accessible through the UNEP website.

REPORT: The report will use survey data for analysis to present responses at the level of countries, regions and types of actions rather than focus on individual actions. Analysis in the report will also examine the links between different questions in the survey, for example between type of action and barriers encountered

DASHBOARD: Data on each activity and action will be publicly available and accessible on the UNEP website.

We will undertake a separate process to check and validate responses where possible. 

When completing the Survey, you will be asked to tick a box to confirm that you agree that information on each action and activity will be made publicly available through the UNEP website. Personal data will not be made publicly available.  Any names of respondents and contact details, such as email addresses, will be kept confidential within the research team and not released. 

What are the questions and how long will the survey take?

We suggest you provide information for up to 10 key actions or activities in total. Your contributions may address any activities considered relevant to marine plastic litter and microplastics and need not be exhaustive.

Questions cover, for example,  the type of action or activity,  the life cycle phase of the plastic targeted, geographic range, environmental zone, partnerships, reporting and evaluation.

You will also be asked to indicate if the action/activity targets specific items (e.g. bottles, fishing  gear, microbeads), impacts (e.g. marine organisms, human health), sectors (e.g., agriculture, tourism), and what the drivers and barriers are related to the action.

The survey is estimated to take around 15  minutes to complete for each action or activity.  Please use a computer to access and complete the survey as it is not suitable for mobile phones. Guidance is available from marinelitterstocktake@plymouth.ac.uk.

Code of Research Ethics

We value your help in this research on current actions and activities. Any personal data you provide (name, role and contact email address) will only be visible to the research team. You also have the right to withdraw from the survey at any point in the survey and can ask for the data to be destroyed.  You can do so by contacting:

marinelitterstocktake@plymouth.ac.uk

In case of complaints please contact the ethics committee hhsethics@plymouth.ac.uk

General Contact:  marinelitterstocktake@plymouth.ac.uk

Click here to download the survey guidance document:

children.label: b42248206
children.text:
Scope of the Survey

For the purpose of this UNEP stock-taking exercise we are interested in the following actions or activites:

*existing now (starting from 1st of January 2018). Click here to download an explanation.

*aimed at the long term elimination of plastic litter and microplastics into the ocean.

*undertaken in or near the ocean as well as further upstream at any point of the plastics lifecycle.

*including direct inputs (e.g., via sewage outflows) and indirect inputs (e.g., via changing packaging materials).

Actions may include regulatory change (e.g., bans, laws), technical change, monitoring programmes and capacity-building in the broadest sense (e.g., information campaigns, education programmes, behaviour change campaigns).

(If you would like more guidance on completing the survey click here to download the guidance document)

First, please tell us a bit about your role:

(If you are visiting the survey more than once, please understand, for data protection purposes, we need you to re-enter this information).

The link to the survey is provided on the final page.

children.label: b42248203
children.text: TYPE OF ACTION: What did the MAIN action/activity focus on? (Please tick ONE which best describes the action you are reporting).

options.text: LEGISLATION, STANDARDS, RULES: e.g. agreeing new or changing rules or standards that others should comply with, new regulation, agreements, policies, economic instruments etc. including voluntary commitments.
WORKING WITH PEOPLE: Encouraging or enabling others (e.g., education, training, communication, awareness raising, behaviour change programmes

TECHNOLOGY and PROCESSES: New technical developments/innovation (e.g., research and development, new product design, new materials, processes etc.) changes in practice, operations, environmental management and planning.
MONITORING and ANALYSIS: Collecting evidence around plastic discharge to the ocean/waterways? (e.g. monitoring, analysis)

children.label: b42254121
children.text: We are interested in how important a systems view and circular economy thinking is to your action/activity (definitions following). A systems view = thinking about the issue systemically, in its context with regard to the interdependence of different factors. A circular economy approach relates to sustainable production and consumption that underpin a circular reduce-reuse-recycle based economy.

children.text:
Actions can sometimes have positive consequences that were unexpected (“co-benefits”).

Are any co-benefits of the action captured in the evaluation?

children.label: b42254156
children.text: Actions can also have unintended negative consequences or risks (“side effects”).  Are any unintended side effects of the action captured in the evaluation?

children.label: b41910088
children.text: There are limited resources for addressing key environmental and social outcomes. Sometimes making efforts towards one thing helps another; sometimes they conflict.   In your view, does a focus on plastic pollution help or hinder progress on other important goals? In other words, can addressing plastic pollution improve other environmental and social issues at the same time? Or do you think focusing on plastic pollution distracts from or conflicts with these other issues? So, please select the statement below that best represents your belief. children.label: b42254288
children.text:
Thank you for taking part in this survey. The information is extremely valuable to us and will be analysed with care, to inform next steps. The information will be collated with the responses from other member states and organisations and will be included in a publicly available inventory of the activities and actions taken by organisations to reduce the discharge of marine plastic litter and microplastics to the seas and oceans. 

The information will be available through the UNEP website, after the finalisation of the work.
